body: Thanks! Merged in trunk. ✨
Thanks! Merged in trunk. ✨

@pquentin no, I'm relying on the tests for that.  Although seeing that the tests rely on saved responses I see your point.  Is there any sort of integration tests that are triggerable that run the "real" api.
Also is there any documentation as to how to generate the responses that are saved and used in the test?  I can imagine that some have them have changed over the years (similar to the object storage api here where all tests passed before this pull request but the real world api broke anyway).

I now upgraded to the most recent api version and checked the object storage tests against actual api calls which all work as expected (I've also upgraded the response fixtures to reflect the response structures I found running against the live api).  However, I have not tested the compute azure / azure arm drivers with real api calls.

@costela it's already available you can use the following URL to get information about our offers:

`https://cp-ams1.scaleway.com/products/servers` to get the different offers for the ams1 zone
`https://cp-ams1.scaleway.com/products/servers/availability`to get the availability within the ams1 zone.

Same goes for `par1` zone.
For the availability, it goes to `scarce` when it hits a first low_stock threshold (that is different for every instance) and `shortage` when it hits the lower second threshold.
@pquentin yes, that is exactly right.

@sieben Ok, so the documentation is outdated, then, because I'm not seeing that endpoint among the options there. I wonder what else I'm not seeing for that reason?

~~@pquentin Do you want that updated before merge, or would that be alright in a second PR?~~

Hi @jdesfossez, thanks for the fix. 

We noticed that our garbage collector started crashing on this since the 26th of April. I could not find any mention of this change in the DigitalOcean changelog. Do you know if we can expect more unannounced (potentially breaking) changes in the DigitalOcean API?

before:
```
In [2]: conn = get_connection('digitalocean')

In [3]: conn.list_volumes()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-f087464ec811> in <module>()
----> 1 conn.list_volumes()

/usr/local/venv/hypernode-control/src/apache-libcloud/libcloud/compute/drivers/digitalocean.pyc in list_volumes(self)
    126     def list_volumes(self):
    127         data = self._paginated_request('/v2/volumes', 'volumes')
--> 128         return list(map(self._to_volume, data))
    129 
    130     def create_node(self, name, size, image, location, ex_create_attr=None,

TypeError: argument 2 to map() must support iteration
```

after:
```
In [1]: from hypernode.provisioning.node_operations import get_connection

In [2]: conn = get_connection('digitalocean')

In [3]: conn.list_volumes()
Out[3]: []
```

Could you add a test to the test-suite to reflect this new behavior? You could add something like this to test_digitalocean_v2.py:

after test_list_volumes_none:
```
    def test_list_volumes_empty(self):
        volumes = self.driver.list_volumes()
        self.assertEqual(len(volumes), 0)
```

and after _v2_volumes_NONE add _v2_volumes_NONE with a fixture like:
```
{
  "volumes": None,
  "links": {},
  "meta": {
    "total": 0
  }
}
```

@danhunsaker I'm working on adding documentation on the developer's documentation https://github.com/scaleway/api.scaleway.com/pull/56 I will warn you once it is merged. 

@pquentin Don't hesitate if you need additional support or if you have questions about Scaleway's services.

Hi all,

This was brought to my attention internally at DigitalOcean, and I want to apologize for any inconvenience. This was an inadvertent change to our API that has now been reverted. We're committed to providing a stable API. If there ever arises a need for a breaking change, it will be communicated in advance as part of a deprecation process. Our API changelog can be found here: https://developers.digitalocean.com/documentation/changelog/

I'm a contributor to libcloud myself, so please feel free to tag me on any questions related to our API.

Sorry again for the disruption to your work.
@jdesfossez @vdloo Can you please confirm than the DigitalOcean fix work for you?
@andrewsomething Thanks! It's great to see such a fast response from DigitalOcean.

Yes, I confirm it works !
Thanks @andrewsomething !

Yes, it works. Thanks for the quick fix @andrewsomething 

```
In [2]: conn = get_connection('digitalocean')

In [3]: conn.list_volumes()
Out[3]: []
```
Great, thanks. @jdesfossez, please close the pull request when you get the chance. :)
OK, we're pulling from the API, now, and I added a check for the actual size of the base image's volume, so we can be sure to create enough volumes to deploy properly. This should be it for this PR.
Perfect so @costela @pquentin what could we do to make it get merged?

We'll need an ICLA from @bonifaido and a review from a libcloud committer, for example me if I find some time to do it.

@sieben I see that you authored two commits, are you happy with the current code?

Indeed I am :) Let me know if I can do something else to move it forward.

Le mer. 9 mai 2018 à 11:44, Quentin Pradet <notifications@github.com> a
écrit :

> We'll need an ICLA from @bonifaido <https://github.com/bonifaido> and a
> review from a libcloud committer, for example me if I find some time to do
> it.
>
> @sieben <https://github.com/sieben> I see that you authored two commits,
> are you happy with the current code?
>

> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.

Hi, what is an ICLA ? :)
@bonifaido http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development.html#contributing-bigger-changes :)

@ZuluPro can you please review this change?

Hello @pquentin @yanowitz 
You've seen I'm on the case ;)

To avoid to update listing manually, I created this package https://github.com/ZuluPro/python-ec2-sizes.
It parses the AWS pricing JSON (>200MB) and stores it as pickles, `dict`s and JSONs.

Do you think we could integrate it to libcloud (as third package or in contrib) ?
@ZuluPro It would make sense to do this before each release, and allow users to do it manually if they want to, yes. Is this what you were thinking about?
@bonifaido Did you signed it?
Finally, I have sent the ICLA to the Apache Secretary email address. :)
Awesome. Thanks for laying the ground work on this one!

Hey @pquentin 
Yep good idea !

Would some squashing be useful before the merge?

Thanks for asking.

What would be really useful would be a rebase on top of trunk! If doing it involes a squash, then that's fine.
I can squash or not in the rebase. I've kept it rebased regularly thus far, so it'll be a matter of a moment to rebase and push again.
Oh, but if the last rebase is recent, then there's no problem, I'll do this myself, there won't be any conflicts.
Yeah, looks like trunk hasn't moved since the last rebase, so it should be good to go. 😊
Here have a squash. :slightly_smiling_face:

@pquentin @alex @yanowitz
What do you think about it ?

It is related to the #1209
And all the ones I did for upgrade AWS instance types & regions.
Sounds good, however I did not take the time to review this in depth yet, sorry. Not sure when it will happen. Other libcloud committers should feel free to look at this!

Well I need to put in some work now. :)

But since you're asking: one thing you could do is review other pull requests.
@tonybaloney What do you think about ?
@cedriccabessa can confirm but the workflow is `available` -> `snapshotting` -> `available`
@sieben So, `available` twice? What does `available` actually communicate to us, then? What would it make the most sense to be mapped to?

Available means that the volume is available for a compute instance. This is the running/normal state. When you are doing a snapshot, the volume gets in the snapshotting state. Once the snapshot is finished the state go back to available. 
So volume-wise I think they are the 2 only states so far.
Hmm. That sounds like the volume state, rather than the snapshot state.
@CedricCabessa can you confirm the snapshot states?

Hi @danhunsaker 
Here is how snapshot works:
When you create a snapshot, the snapshot object is immediately created but it is not yet usable: the state of the snapshot object is **snapshotting**. In order to avoid to poweroff a VM while a snapshot is in progress, the volume is also in state **snapshotting**
After a few seconds/minute, the snapshot is finished: the volume and the snapshot are both in state **available**, and you can use your snasphot to create a new instance.

Sometime, the snapshot can fail. In this case the snapshot will be in state **error** and the volume will be set to **available**

As @sieben said; for volume you have **available** and **snapshotting**, and for snapshot you have **available**, **snapshotting** and **error**

Also note that this is for hotsnapshot, for coldsnapshot (when the VM is powered off), everything is simpler and snapshot are done instantaneously so the volume and snapshot are always **available**

Feel free to ping me if you have more questions :-)
Perfect. That's exactly what I needed for this one. Any info on the other question, about the root volume always being volume zero for the server?
@danhunsaker yes, the root volume is always volume 0
Great, thanks!

@danhunsaker My understanding of the current state is that you now have enough information to resolve the two TODOs and you need to answer the pagination question above: is it too much work to support pagination explicitly in each method?

Right. Sorry for the delay.

It feels like making the user explicitly handle pagination on their own removes some of the benefit of abstraction, but it's not my call, really, as I'm just contributing, here. I do think something consistent across all providers would be the most beneficial, in any case. It sounds like no such standard approach exists, though.

Pushing a commit now with the TODOs resolved (one just needed the comment removed). Will investigate the proposed pagination approach and see what I can figure out, there.

OK, let's not block this PR for the pagination issue. I'll review your change when I get the chance. (In that case a new commit would have been better.)

Thanks!

Oops. Actually just pushed another squashed commit right before you posted that. This time, with a different pagination approach.

It's somewhere between the previous approach and what ECS is doing - it's an alternate `request` method on the `ScalewayConnection` class. It pulls the logic out of the response class and into the actual request handling, which should be much more clear about what's going on and how.
Oh I see you already made the recursion change. Thanks, I think that's much better.
I take too long to type things sometimes. :grin: Pretty sure that's everything requested on this one.

The docstring says:

        :param  routing_mode: Create network with 'Global' or 'Regional'
                              routing mode for BGP advertisements.
                              Defaults to 'Regional'
        :type   routing_mode: ``str`` or ``None``

Maybe the correct fix is to set routing_mode to `Regional` if it's None?

That default happens on Google's end rather than ours, and they seem to prefer not sending a value at all unless you have an explicit preference for one or the other. But that's certainly an option as well. I was just opting for actually supporting `None`, as the docstring also indicates is valid.
Thanks, that makes sense, I'll merge this when I have the chance.
There we go. Both changes as their own commits. Hope that helps!
That's a much better approach!

@ZuluPro Thanks! I have one more question.

The 'capacitystatus', 'ebsOptimized', 'operation', 'licenseModel', 'preInstalledSw', 'tenancy', 'usagetype' fields in extra are not deterministic because they actually vary across regions. Should we leave them out?

@ZuluPro I ended up leaving them out. See https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/384e42336e073594acccb5ad1c0e873830c9a06c

Merci Anthony ! Merged in trunk. ✨

works as intended
```python
In [10]: mynode = conn.create_node(name=name, size=size, image=image, location=location, ex_create_attr={'ssh_keys': ['1234'], 'tags': ['mytag1', 'mytag2']})

In [11]: mynode.extra['tags']
Out[11]: [u'mytag1', u'mytag2']
```
lgtm :+1: thanks for the contribution!
